content.content: If MakerDAO is committing MKR to the subDAOs and running valuation analysis based on factors like cash flows, that seems like it would place subDAO tokens firmly in the securities category. Are there plans for how address the legal implications of that in various jurisdictions?
content.GPT-summary: The post is asking a question about the legal implications of MakerDAO's commitment to subDAOs and how it affects the classification of subDAO tokens as securities in different jurisdictions. The post also provides constructive criticism by pointing out the potential legal issues that may arise. It can be categorized as a question about the proposal, constructive criticism, and auditing/reviewing the proposal.

content.content: By that logic doing a valuation model of the transaction fees ethereum earns would turn ETH into a security. Luckily that’s not how it works. Instead, it’s all a question of decentralization, and the number one way to reduce the regulatory attack surface is to ensure real decentralization is in place. The endgame plan delivers this for Maker Core through voter incentives, and the SubDAOs inherit the decentralization of Maker Core since their own governance execution runs on top of Maker Core defined by the processes that will be described in the Endgame Constitution and the Governance Security scope. The clusters that aim to onboard into working for the SubDAOs after they have launched, need to of course have solid legal structures and have their lawyers do important analysis about when actions would go beyond the mandate of facilitating and providing advice for the voters, and risk turning them into an actual operating agent of the SubDAO in the jurisdictions they have exposure to. The 250k structuring startup grant that every cluster gets is supposed to help with resources for this kind of initial work. Eventually, the final stage will be full mandatory pseudonymity of all Maker Core and SubDAO mandated actors, and beyond that point it is possible that the roles would begin to be replaced by AI, enabling an even greater level of decentralization.

The difference between this and Eth is that MakerDAO isn’t issuing ETH and has minimal influence over the asset. If MakerDAO is running cashflow analysis on an asset it is issuing, that is strong evidence that this asset is being issued with an expectation of profit. If MakerDAO is committing to buy up tokens or provide the SubDAO with assets, that makes the token’s value dependent on the efforts of others.     rune:  Instead, it’s all a question of decentralization, and the number one way to reduce the regulatory attack surface is to ensure real decentralization is in place.   Where is decentralization mentioned in securities laws? Or do you mean decentralization will allow MakerDAO to ignore securities laws?     rune:  Eventually, the final stage will be full mandatory pseudonymity of all Maker Core and SubDAO mandated actors, and beyond that point it is possible that the roles would begin to be replaced by AI, enabling an even greater level of decentralization.   It will be many years before this is feasible. Is MakerDAO just hoping no prosecution occurs in the meantime?

Well for the US there’s the Howey test and for EU there’s MiCA. If you want to keep talking about regulation I’ll be happy to answer, but can you please make a new thread so this one can be used for actually discussing the tokenomics?

Hate to say this but don’t waste your time and brain cells engaging with Rune about these topics. He will only spin up a web of long-winded distraction and non-sense while failing to answer your question (the actual answer is “I don’t care about securities laws and I haven’t given them any thought aside from a superficial focus on ‘muh dECentRAlization’”). Rune is single handedly destroying the value of MKR holders’ assets while pumping unworkable schemes into the DAO for polar bears and fantasies about investing in nuclear power plants. Can’t believe this project is going down the tubes.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal

content.content: Rune is doing his best to ensure the success of the project. While one may not agree with all of his actions, he cares about MakerDAO. His efforts to engage a wider base of stakeholders and diversify MKR holders in the long term is only shot the project has at a future.
Endgame appears to be another utopian fantasy that is likely to wind up in the dust bin of history
This topic was automatically closed 91 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
